member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.EmptyGuidBehaviorExpectation
member.summary: Encapsulates the expected behavior when an (typically representing a method or constructor) is invoked with a argument.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.EmptyGuidBehaviorExpectation.Verify(Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IGuardClauseCommand)
member.summary: Verifies the behavior of the command when invoked with .
member.param: The command whose behavior must be examined.

remarks.para: This method encapsulates the behavior which is expected when a method or constructor is invoked with as one of the method arguments. In that case it's expected that invoking with Guid.Empty throws an , causing the Verify method to succeed. If other exceptions are thrown, or no exception is thrown when invoking the command, the Verify method throws an exception.

member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IExpansion`1
member.summary: Represents an operation that somehow expands a single value into a sequence.
member.typeparam: The type of item being expanded.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IExpansion`1.Expand(`0)
member.summary: Expands a value into a sequence of values.

remarks.para: In a sense, an expansion is the opposite as an aggregation. Given a single value the result is a sequence produced from the value. There's no inherent definition on how such a sequence is produced or what the values in the sequence will be. may or may not be contained in the result.

Implementations could, for example, simply produce a sequence with the input value as the single element, or it could produce a sequence where the input value is repeated a number of times. Other options are also possible.

member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IndexedReplacement`1
member.summary: Replaces an indexed element in a sequence with a given value.
member.typeparam: The type of the items in the sequences consumed and produced.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IndexedReplacement`1.#ctor(System.Int32,`0[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The index of the element which should be replaced.
The sequence in which an element should be replaced.

remarks.para: When is invoked, the element at in will be replaced by the new value. The index is zero-based.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IndexedReplacement`1.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The index of the element which should be replaced.
The sequence in which an element should be replaced.

remarks.para: When is invoked, the element at in will be replaced by the new value. The index is zero-based.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IndexedReplacement`1.Expand(`0)
member.summary: Replaces the pre-selected element in the source sequence with a new element.
member.param: The value which will replace the existing element.
member.returns: A copy of where the pre-selected element has been replaced with .

remarks.para: This method replaces an element in with . The element to be replaced is the element at the . The replacement is not done directly in the , but rather in a copy which is then returned by the method call.

member.name: P:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IndexedReplacement`1.ReplacementIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the element which will be replaced by the method.

remarks.para: The index is zero-based.

member.name: P:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IndexedReplacement`1.Source
member.summary: Gets the sequence of elements where one element will be replaced by the method.

member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.NullReferenceBehaviorExpectation
member.summary: Encapsulates expectations about the behavior of a method or constructor when it's invoked with a null argument.

remarks.para: The NullReferenceBehaviorExpectation class encapsulates the following expectation: when an action (such as a method call or constructor invocation) is performed with a argument it should raise an . If this happens the expectation is verified. If no exception, or any other type of exception, is thrown the expectation isn't met.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.NullReferenceBehaviorExpectation.Verify(Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IGuardClauseCommand)
member.summary: Verifies that the command behaves correct when invoked with a null argument.
member.param: The command whose behavior must be examined.

remarks.para: The Verify method attempts to invoke the instance's with . The expected result is that this action throws an , in which case the expected behavior is considered verified. If any other exception is thrown, or if no exception is thrown at all, the verification fails and an exception is thrown.
The behavior is only asserted if the command's is nullable. In case of value types, no action is performed.

member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IdiomaticAssertion
member.summary: Base implementation of .

remarks.para: IdiomaticAssertion provides default implementations of all methods of , making sure that higher-order methods call into lower-order methods; e.g. that calls with all public types in the assembly.
Implementers can override the appropriate methods instead of creating an implementation of IIdiomaticAssertion completely from scratch.

member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.IIdiomaticAssertion
member.summary: Represents an encapsulation of an idiomatic unit test assertion based on Reflection types.

remarks.para: Some unit tests tend to be very repeatable, following common idioms. Some such idiomatic tests can be expressed as general methods based on their or other Reflection-based instances.

member.name: T:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.WritablePropertyAssertion
member.summary: Encapsulates a unit test that verifies that a writable property is correctly implemented.

remarks.para: According to the framework design guidelines, a writable property should always have both a setter and getter. In order not to violate the Principle of Least Astonishment the getter should always return the object assigned via the setter. Thus, for every writable property one should always write a unit test that verifies that the value read from the proeprty is the same as the value assigned to the property.
However, such unit tests become tedious and repetitive to write; together, they form a unit testing idiom for .NET. This encapsulates this idiom.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.WritablePropertyAssertion.#ctor(Ploeh.AutoFixture.Kernel.ISpecimenBuilderComposer)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A composer which can create instances required to implement the idiomatic unit test, such as the owner of the property, as well as the value to be assigned and read from the property.

remarks.para: will typically be a instance.

member.name: M:Ploeh.AutoFixture.Idioms.WritablePropertyAssertion.Verify(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Verifies that a writable property is correctly implemented.

remarks.para: This method verifies that is correctly implemented as a writable property. It used the to create an instance of the Type on which the property is implemented and then assigns to and reads from the property. The assertion passes if the value read from the property is the same as the value assigned to it. If this is not the case, a is thrown.
This method does nothing if the property is not a writable property.
